p: The different plant parts used by TMPs to make their medicinal products for patient administration are shown in Table 5. These plant parts include leaves, roots, bark, seeds, the fruit and, in one case, the whole plant. The leaves and roots were the most used plant parts among the plants cited. In 13 plant species (72.2%), roots and leaves were the useful plants parts, in 7 plant species (38.9%), the bark was used; whilst seeds and fruits were the plant parts used in 5 (27.8%) and 4 (22.2%) plant species. It was also noted that, as shown in Table 3, these plant species were not only useful for treatment of cancer, but also, for multiple other medical ailments. A single plant could be used for more than one ailment. It was also important to note that, out of the plant species obtained in this study, a number of them were cultivated or brought from neighbouring countries such as South Africa and Botswana by some of the practitioners, namely herbalists. These plants could no longer be easily found in the wild, locally. These species included Sutherlandia frutescens (L.)R.Br. , Prunus persica (L.) Batsch , Duranta erecta L. , Bulbinella floribunda (Thunb.) T. Durand & Schinz , Cannabis sativa L. and Hibiscus sabdariffa L.
